awd_titl_txt: Scholarships Targeting Recruitment of Individuals for Degrees in Environmental Science (STRIDES)
awd_abstract_narration:
Broward College (BC) is both a Hispanic Serving Institution (HSI) and a Minority Serving Institution (MSI). The college offers bachelor's and associate degree programs and certificate programs.  A 2+2 program in Environmental Science offers an experiential learning curriculum which combines general cognitive and workplace knowledge with applied science and industry specific skills. This five-year project entitled "Scholarships Targeting Recruitment of Individuals for Degrees in Environmental Science" (STRIDES) is selecting 30 high ability, low-income students recruited from one of three cohorts chosen to participate in a new bachelor's degree program which has BioSecurity as one focus. Students complete an internship, independent study or a research project as part of the program. The program is developed in response to an unmet need in the geographical region for biological/environmental science graduates. Program staff work with local companies to provide internships, job shadowing, industry mentoring and jobs for students. 

Research focuses on a study of retention rates via analysis of various aspects of the problem such as financial assistance and the level of Perceived Education Support (PER) with a comparison of community guided research versus faculty guided research as parameters. The program provides students a combination of campus based and field activities which reinforce learning through individual and group work. The college's Academic Support Centers (ASCs) offer academic support, tutoring and career exploration programs. STRIDES students work one-on-one with subject matter experts located in the newly established STEM Center to deepen conceptual knowledge and understanding. Tutors working in ASC's are required to attend training to become certified in order to practice. Faculty who are active members of professional societies and community research receive training in the mentorship of students. The Management Team comprises faculty, STEM administrators, a Support Services administrator and a researcher. Project evaluation(both formative and summative)is accomplished by both internal (BC's Institutional Research department) and external experts (MN Associates). Program assessment occurs at the end of each semester. The database tracks year to year retention and graduation rates for women, minorities and transfer students. Data from prior years serves as a benchmark for success in improving retention and graduation rates.

por.por_cntn:
Scholarships Targeting Recruitment of Individuals for Degrees in Environmental Sciences (STRIDES) ran 2016-2022 at Broward College (Ft. Lauderdale, FL). Broward College (BC) is a large, urban minority serving state college.It is a commuter college with no on-campus housing. As of 2021-2022, it has an enrollment of 55,854 with 81% being part-time students, 53% being Pell-grant eligible, and 46% being First Generation college students. The majority of students at BC are non-traditional students, who tend to be older than 18-21, have children, and live independently. Thirty-five percent of students are Hispanic, 30% are Black, and 14% are white with 55% of students being female and 36% male.

STRIDES supported 51 Scholars, a diverse group of academically talented, financially needy students enrolled in Environmental Science.

The program supported students as they entered and graduated from BC’s 2+2 Environmental Science program that culminates in a Bachelor of Science in Environmental Science. The objectives of STRIDES were to:-Increase the number of full-time students majoring in Biosecurity and Physical Science tracks in Environmental Science;-Increase the number of low income and minority graduates in the field of Environmental Science;-Enrich the educational opportunities for students receiving NSF scholarship support;-Expose students to real-world opportunities to apply their classroom knowledge through co-operative education;-Engage students in faculty led research typical of what they might encounter in graduate school.

Intellectual Merit :STRIDES provided students access to numerous innovative initiatives in Environmental Science, including cutting-edge research being conducted at BC and at institutions that host BC interns. The project investigated the role and impact of these additional financial and enhanced holistic supports on student success. Broader Impacts :The broader impacts of STRIDES included providing students from underrepresented, economically disadvantaged groups that BC serves with not only funds for their education, but also essential support services to help them obtain degrees and high-wage, high skill employment.

The STRIDES program had to shift investigative models due to unforeseen events such as 5 hurricanes, the Covid-19 pandemic, and bureaucratic complications, all of which impacted cohort structures, planned activities, instructional methods, and communications. In addition, with Scholars taking different classes at multiple campuses in different modalities, the planned cohort system quickly broke down. Anecdotally, a cohort based analytical model may not be appropriate for large, multi-campus institutions like BC due to the diaspora of Scholars within it. 

The portion of the STRIDES program examining perceived social support as a marker of student success was also disrupted which resulted in insufficient data being collected to properly analyze. Based on lessons learned from the STRIDES project, future projects studying this potential factor will incorporate different methodologies necessary to attain sufficient data.

Despite the early belief that due to its affordability, even a small award would substantially relieve BC students of financial burdens that inhibit their academic success, STRIDES found that this was not the case for the majority of the Scholars. Nearly all of them continued to work, many full-time or nearly full-time, while simultaneously enrolled full-time (30 credits per year).

Qualitatively, the STRIDES program found that academic intensity was a compelling factor in student success. Students who performed well at the part-time level struggled to maintain their prior level of academic achievement when required to enroll full-time. This seemed to be compounded by non-traditional student factors (e.g. employment, family responsibilities, etc.).

The STRIDES program offered special events and workshops. Scholars also had opportunities to travel to scientific conferences, society meetings, and professional gatherings, held locally, nationally, and internationally. Scholars presented posters on research they engaged in, including at international conferences.

Of the 51 STRIDES Scholars, 30 graduated with their BS degree, 3 will graduate in December 2022, with the remaining 18 leaving the program (e.g. leave of absence, left academic program, dismissed due to GPA, etc.).

Of the STRIDES BS graduates to date, 3 work as STEM educators, 4 work in industry, 10 in governmental agencies, 3 work in STEM focused NGOs, 3 entered health science professional schools (MD and PA), and 4 entered funded graduate schools (MS and PhD). This met the main goal of the S-STEM program and the STRIDES program, which is to funnel academically talented underrepresented groups into STEM careers.


Last Modified: 12/15/2022
Modified by: Christine Sammon
